**Black Panther** is a fictional [superhero](/wiki/Superhero "Superhero")
appearing in [American comic books](/wiki/American_comic_books "American comic
books") published by [Marvel Comics](/wiki/Marvel_Comics "Marvel Comics"). The
character was created by writer-editor [Stan Lee](/wiki/Stan_Lee "Stan Lee")
and writer-artist [Jack Kirby](/wiki/Jack_Kirby "Jack Kirby"), first appearing
in _[Fantastic Four](/wiki/Fantastic_Four_\(comic_book\) "Fantastic Four
\(comic book\)")_ #52 ([cover-dated](/wiki/Cover-date "Cover-date") July 1966)
in the [Silver Age of Comic Books](/wiki/Silver_Age_of_Comic_Books "Silver Age
of Comic Books"). Black Panther's real name is **T 'Challa**, king and
protector of the fictional African nation of
[Wakanda](/wiki/Wakanda_\(comics\) "Wakanda \(comics\)"). Along with
possessing enhanced abilities achieved through ancient Wakandan rituals of
drinking the essence of the heart-shaped herb, T'Challa also relies on his
proficiency in science, rigorous physical training, hand-to-hand combat
skills, and access to wealth and advanced Wakandan technology to combat his
enemies.

Black Panther is the first superhero of African descent in mainstream American
comics, having debuted years before early [African
American](/wiki/African_American "African American") superheroes such as
Marvel Comics' the [Falcon](/wiki/Falcon_\(comics\) "Falcon \(comics\)")
(1969), [Luke Cage](/wiki/Luke_Cage "Luke Cage") (1972) and
[Blade](/wiki/Blade_\(comics\) "Blade \(comics\)") (1973), or [DC
Comics](/wiki/DC_Comics "DC Comics")' [John
Stewart](/wiki/John_Stewart_\(comics\) "John Stewart \(comics\)") in the role
of [Green Lantern](/wiki/Green_Lantern "Green Lantern") (1971). In one comic
book storyline, the Black Panther mantle is handled by [Kasper
Cole](/wiki/White_Tiger_\(Kasper_Cole\) "White Tiger \(Kasper Cole\)"), a
multiracial [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") [police
officer](/wiki/New_York_City_Police_Department "New York City Police
Department"). Beginning as an impersonator, Cole would later take on the
moniker of White Tiger and become an ally to T'Challa. The role of Black
Panther and leadership of Wakanda is also given to T'Challa's sister
[Shuri](/wiki/Shuri_\(comics\) "Shuri \(comics\)") for a time when he is left
recovering from critical injuries.

Black Panther has made numerous appearances in various television shows,
animated films and video games. The character is portrayed in live action by
[Chadwick Boseman](/wiki/Chadwick_Boseman "Chadwick Boseman") in the 2016 film
_[Captain America: Civil War](/wiki/Captain_America:_Civil_War "Captain
America: Civil War")_ , and the 2018 films _[Black
Panther](/wiki/Black_Panther_\(film\) "Black Panther \(film\)")_ and
_[Avengers: Infinity War](/wiki/Avengers:_Infinity_War "Avengers: Infinity
War")_ , set in the [Marvel Cinematic
Universe](/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe "Marvel Cinematic Universe").

In 2011, Black Panther was ranked 51st overall on [IGN](/wiki/IGN "IGN")'s
"Top 100 Comic Books Heroes" list.[1]

## Concept and
creation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Concept and creation")]

###
Name[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Name")]

The Black Panther's name predates the October 1966 founding of the [Black
Panther Party](/wiki/Black_Panther_Party "Black Panther Party"), though not
the black panther logo of the party's predecessor, the [Lowndes County Freedom
Organization](/wiki/Student_Nonviolent_Coordinating_Committee#Lowndes_County_Freedom_Organization
"Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee") (LCFO), nor the
[segregated](/wiki/Racial_segregation "Racial segregation") [World War
II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") [Black Panthers Tank
Battalion](/wiki/761st_Tank_Battalion_\(United_States\) "761st Tank Battalion
\(United States\)").[2][3] Stan Lee, co-creator of the comic, denied that the
comic was named after any of the political uses of the term "black panther",
including the LCFO, citing "a strange coincidence".[4] He is the first black
superhero in American mainstream [comic books](/wiki/Comic_book "Comic book");
very few black heroes were created before him, and none with actual
superpowers. These included the characters in the single-issue, low-
distribution _[All-Negro Comics](/wiki/All-Negro_Comics "All-Negro Comics")_
#1 (1947); Waku, Prince of the Bantu, who starred in his own feature in the
omnibus title _[Jungle Tales](/wiki/Jungle_Tales "Jungle Tales")_ , from
Marvel's 1950s predecessor, [Atlas Comics](/wiki/Atlas_Comics_\(1950s\) "Atlas
Comics \(1950s\)"); and the [Dell Comics](/wiki/Dell_Comics "Dell Comics")
[Western](/wiki/Western_comics "Western comics") character
[Lobo](/wiki/Lobo_\(Dell_Comics\) "Lobo \(Dell Comics\)"), the first black
person to star in his own comic book. Previous
non-[caricatured](/wiki/Caricature "Caricature") black supporting characters
in comics include [U.S. Army](/wiki/United_States_Army "United States Army")
[infantry](/wiki/Infantry "Infantry") private [Gabriel Jones](/wiki/Gabe_Jones
"Gabe Jones") of _[Sgt. Fury and his Howling
Commandos](/wiki/Sgt._Fury_and_his_Howling_Commandos "Sgt. Fury and his
Howling Commandos")_.

In a guest appearance in _Fantastic Four_ #119 (Feb. 1972), the Black Panther
briefly tried using the name **Black Leopard** to avoid connotations with the
Party, but the new name did not last.[5] The character's name was changed back
to **Black Panther** in _Avengers_ #105, with T'Challa explaining that
renaming himself made as much sense as altering the [Scarlet
Witch](/wiki/Scarlet_Witch "Scarlet Witch")'s name, and he is not a
stereotype.[6]

Co-creator [Stan Lee](/wiki/Stan_Lee "Stan Lee") recounted that the name was
inspired by a pulp adventure hero who has a [black
panther](/wiki/Black_panther "Black panther") as a helper.[7] Jack Kirby's
original concept art for Black Panther used the concept name Coal Tiger.[8]

### Publication
history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Publication history")]

Following his debut in _[Fantastic Four](/wiki/Fantastic_Four_\(comic_book\)
"Fantastic Four \(comic book\)")_ #52–53 (July–Aug. 1966) and subsequent guest
appearance in _Fantastic Four Annual_ #5 (1967) and with [Captain
America](/wiki/Captain_America "Captain America") in _[Tales of
Suspense](/wiki/Tales_of_Suspense "Tales of Suspense")_ #97–100 (Jan.– April
1968), the Black Panther journeyed from the fictional [African](/wiki/Africa
"Africa") nation of [Wakanda](/wiki/Wakanda_\(comics\) "Wakanda \(comics\)")
to [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") to join the titular
American superhero team in _[The Avengers](/wiki/The_Avengers_\(comic_book\)
"The Avengers \(comic book\)")_ #52 (May 1968), appearing in that comic for
the next few years. During his time with the Avengers, he made solo guest-
appearances in three issues of
_[Daredevil](/wiki/Daredevil_\(Marvel_Comics_series\) "Daredevil \(Marvel
Comics series\)")_ , and fought [Doctor Doom](/wiki/Doctor_Doom "Doctor Doom")
in _[Astonishing Tales](/wiki/Astonishing_Tales "Astonishing Tales")_ #6–7
(June & Aug. 1971), in that [supervillain](/wiki/Supervillain
"Supervillain")'s short-lived starring feature.

He received his first starring feature with _[Jungle
Action](/wiki/Jungle_Action "Jungle Action")_ #5 (July 1973), a reprint of the
Panther-centric story in _The Avengers_ #62 (March 1969). A new series began
running the following issue, written by [Don McGregor](/wiki/Don_McGregor "Don
McGregor"), with art by [pencilers](/wiki/Pencilers "Pencilers") [Rich
Buckler](/wiki/Rich_Buckler "Rich Buckler"), [Gil Kane](/wiki/Gil_Kane "Gil
Kane"), and [Billy Graham](/wiki/Billy_Graham_\(comics\) "Billy Graham
\(comics\)"), and which gave inkers [Klaus Janson](/wiki/Klaus_Janson "Klaus
Janson") and [Bob McLeod](/wiki/Bob_McLeod_\(comics\) "Bob McLeod \(comics\)")
some of their first professional exposure. The critically acclaimed[9] series
ran in _Jungle Action_ #6–24 (Sept. 1973 – Nov. 1976).[10]

One now-common format McGregor pioneered was that of the self-contained,
multi-issue story arc.[11] The first, "Panther's Rage", ran through the first
13 issues. Critic Jason Sacks has called the arc "Marvel's first [graphic
novel](/wiki/Graphic_novel "Graphic novel")":

> [T]here were real character arcs in [Spider-Man](/wiki/Spider-Man "Spider-
> Man") and the [Fantastic Four](/wiki/Fantastic_Four "Fantastic Four")
> [comics] over time. But ... "Panther's Rage" is the first comic that was
> created from start to finish as a complete novel. Running in two years'
> issues of _Jungle Action_ (#s 6 through 18), "Panther's Rage" is a 200-page
> novel that journeys to the heart of the African nation of Wakanda, a nation
> ravaged by a revolution against its king, T'Challa, the Black Panther.[11]

The second and final arc, "Panther vs. the Klan", ran as mostly 17-page
stories in _Jungle Action_ #19–24 (Jan.–Nov. 1976), except for issue #23, a
reprint of _Daredevil_ #69 (Oct. 1970), in which the Black Panther guest-
starred.[10] The subject matter of the [Ku Klux Klan](/wiki/Ku_Klux_Klan "Ku
Klux Klan") was considered controversial in the Marvel offices at the time,
creating difficulties for the creative team.[12]

African-American writer-editor [Dwayne McDuffie](/wiki/Dwayne_McDuffie "Dwayne
McDuffie") said of the _Jungle Action_ "Black Panther" feature:

> This overlooked and underrated classic is arguably the most tightly written
> multi-part superhero epic ever. If you can get your hands on it ... sit down
> and read the whole thing. It's damn-near flawless, every issue, every scene,
> a functional, necessary part of the whole. Okay, now go back and read any
> individual issue. You'll find seamlessly integrated words and pictures;
> clearly introduced characters and situations; a concise (sometimes even
> transparent) recap; beautifully developed character relationships; at least
> one cool new villain; a stunning action set piece to test our hero's skills
> and resolve; and a story that is always moving forward towards a definite
> and satisfying conclusion. That's what we should all be delivering, every
> single month. Don [McGregor] and company did it in only 17 story pages per
> issue.[9]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/59/Jungleaction23.png/220px-
Jungleaction23.png)](/wiki/File:Jungleaction23.png)

[](/wiki/File:Jungleaction23.png "Enlarge")

Cover of _[Jungle Action](/wiki/Jungle_Action "Jungle Action")_ #23 (Sept.
1976). Art by [John Byrne](/wiki/John_Byrne_\(comics\) "John Byrne
\(comics\)") and [Dan Adkins](/wiki/Dan_Adkins "Dan Adkins").

Though popular with college students, the overall sales of _Jungle Action_
were low,[13] and Marvel relaunched the Black Panther in a self-titled series,
bringing in the character's co-creator [Jack Kirby](/wiki/Jack_Kirby "Jack
Kirby")—newly returned to Marvel after having decamped to rival [DC
Comics](/wiki/DC_Comics "DC Comics") for a time—as writer, penciler, and
editor. However, Kirby wanted to work on new characters and was unhappy at
being assigned a series starring a character he had already worked with
extensively.[14] He left the series after only 12 issues and was replaced by
[Ed Hannigan](/wiki/Ed_Hannigan "Ed Hannigan") (writer), [Jerry
Bingham](/wiki/Jerry_Bingham "Jerry Bingham") (penciler), and [Roger
Stern](/wiki/Roger_Stern "Roger Stern") (editor). _Black Panther_ ran 15
issues (Jan. 1977 – May 1979).[15] Due to the series's cancellation, the
contents of what would have been _Black Panther_ #16–18 were published in
_[Marvel Premiere](/wiki/Marvel_Premiere "Marvel Premiere")_ #51–53.

A four-issue [miniseries](/wiki/Miniseries "Miniseries"), _Black Panther_ vol.
2,[16] (July–Oct. 1988) was written by [Peter B. Gillis](/wiki/Peter_B._Gillis
"Peter B. Gillis") and penciled by [Denys Cowan](/wiki/Denys_Cowan "Denys
Cowan").[17] McGregor revisited his Panther saga with [Gene
Colan](/wiki/Gene_Colan "Gene Colan") in "Panther's Quest", published as 25
eight-page installments within the bi-weekly [anthology](/wiki/Anthology
"Anthology") series _[Marvel Comics Presents](/wiki/Marvel_Comics_Presents
"Marvel Comics Presents")_ (issues #13–37, Feb.–Dec. 1989).[18] He later
teamed with artist [Dwayne Turner](/wiki/Dwayne_Turner "Dwayne Turner") in the
square-bound miniseries _Black Panther: Panther 's Prey_ (Sept. 1990 – March
1991).[19] McGregor conceived a fifth arc in his Black Panther saga, titled
"Panther's Vows", but it failed to get off the ground.[13]

Writer [Christopher Priest](/wiki/Christopher_Priest_\(comics\) "Christopher
Priest \(comics\)")'s and penciller [Mark Texeira](/wiki/Mark_Texeira "Mark
Texeira")'s 1998 series _The Black Panther_ vol. 3 used [Erik
Killmonger](/wiki/Erik_Killmonger "Erik Killmonger"), [Venomm](/wiki/Venomm
"Venomm"), and other characters introduced in "Panther's Rage", together with
new characters such as State Department attorney Everett Ross; the Black
Panther's adopted brother, Hunter; and the Panther's protégé, Queen Divine
Justice. The Priest-Texeira series was under the [Marvel
Knights](/wiki/Marvel_Knights "Marvel Knights") imprint in its first year.
Priest said the creation of character Ross contributed heavily to his decision
to write the series. "I realized I could use Ross to bridge the gap between
the African culture that the Black Panther mythos is steeped in and the
predominantly white readership that Marvel sells to," adding that in his
opinion, the Black Panther had been misused in the years after his
creation.[20]

The last 13 issues (#50–62) saw the main character replaced by a
[multiracial](/wiki/Multiracial "Multiracial") [New York City police
officer](/wiki/New_York_City_Police_Department "New York City Police
Department") named [Kasper Cole](/wiki/Kasper_Cole "Kasper Cole"), with
T'Challa relegated to a supporting character. This Black Panther, who became
the [White Tiger](/wiki/White_Tiger_\(comics\)#Kasper_Cole "White Tiger
\(comics\)"), was placed in the series _[The Crew](/wiki/The_Crew_\(comics\)
"The Crew \(comics\)")_ , running concurrently with the final few _Black
Panther_ issues. _The Crew_ was canceled with issue #7.

In 2005, Marvel began publishing _Black Panther_ vol. 4,[21] which ran 41
issues (April 2005 – Nov. 2008).[22] It was initially written by filmmaker
[Reginald Hudlin](/wiki/Reginald_Hudlin "Reginald Hudlin") (through issue #38)
and penciled by [John Romita, Jr.](/wiki/John_Romita,_Jr. "John Romita, Jr.")
(through #6). Hudlin said he wanted to add "[street cred](/wiki/Credibility
"Credibility")" to the title, although he noted that the book was not
necessarily or primarily geared toward an African-American readership.[23] As
influences for his characterization of the character, Hudlin has cited comic
character [Batman](/wiki/Batman "Batman"), film director [Spike
Lee](/wiki/Spike_Lee "Spike Lee"), and music artist [Sean
Combs](/wiki/Sean_Combs "Sean Combs").[23] Other influences include historical
figures such as 14th-century [Mali Empire](/wiki/Mali_Empire "Mali Empire")
sultan [Mansa Musa](/wiki/Mansa_Musa "Mansa Musa") and 20th-century Jamaican
activist [Marcus Garvey](/wiki/Marcus_Garvey "Marcus Garvey"), as well as
[Biblical](/wiki/Biblical "Biblical") figures such as
[Ham](/wiki/Ham_\(son_of_Noah\) "Ham \(son of Noah\)") and
[Canaan](/wiki/Canaan_\(son_of_Ham\) "Canaan \(son of Ham\)").[24]

_Black Panther_ vol. 5[25] launched in February 2009, with Hudlin, again
scripting, introducing a successor Black Panther, T'Challa's sister
Shuri.[26][27][28] Hudlin co-wrote issue #7 with [Jonathan
Maberry](/wiki/Jonathan_Maberry "Jonathan Maberry"), who then became the new
writer,[29] joined by artist Will Conrad.[30] The Panther was also a featured
player, with members of the Fantastic Four and the [X-Men](/wiki/X-Men
"X-Men"), in the Doctor Doom-based, six-issue miniseries _Doomwar_
(April–Sept. 2010).[31]

T'Challa then accepted an invitation from Matt Murdock, the superhero
Daredevil, to become the new protector of New York City's [Hell's
Kitchen](/wiki/Hell%27s_Kitchen,_Manhattan "Hell's Kitchen, Manhattan")
neighborhood. He became the lead character in _Daredevil_ beginning with issue
#513 (Feb. 2011), when that series was retitled _Black Panther: The Man
Without Fear_.[32] Under writer David Liss and artist Francesco Francavilla,
he took on the identity of Mr. Okonkwo, an immigrant from the [Democratic
Republic of the Congo](/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_the_Congo "Democratic
Republic of the Congo"), and becomes the owner of a small diner in order to be
close to the people.[33]

A new _Black Panther_ series written by [Ta-Nehisi Coates](/wiki/Ta-
Nehisi_Coates "Ta-Nehisi Coates") and drawn by [Brian
Stelfreeze](/wiki/Brian_Stelfreeze "Brian Stelfreeze") was launched in 2016
and continues to be published with Coates as the head writer.[34][35][36]

In 2017, the [afrofuturist](/wiki/Afrofuturist "Afrofuturist") writer [Nnedi
Okorafor](/wiki/Nnedi_Okorafor "Nnedi Okorafor") wrote the series _Black
Panther: Long Live the King_.[37]

### Early life and
background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Early life and background")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/65/Avengers52.jpg/170px-
Avengers52.jpg)](/wiki/File:Avengers52.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Avengers52.jpg "Enlarge")

Debut of the short-lived cowl mask on the cover of _[The
Avengers](/wiki/Avengers_\(comics\) "Avengers \(comics\)")_ #52 (May 1968).
Art by [John Buscema](/wiki/John_Buscema "John Buscema").

The Black Panther is the ceremonial title given to the chief of the Panther
Tribe of the advanced African nation of Wakanda. In addition to ruling the
country, he is also chief of its various tribes (collectively referred to as
the Wakandas). The Panther habit is a symbol of office (head of state) and is
used even during diplomatic missions. The Panther is a hereditary title, but
one must still earn it.

In the distant past, a [meteorite](/wiki/Meteorite "Meteorite") made of the
(fictional) vibration-absorbing mineral [vibranium](/wiki/Vibranium
"Vibranium") crashed in Wakanda, and was unearthed. Reasoning that outsiders
would exploit Wakanda for this valuable resource, the ruler, King
[T'Chaka](/wiki/T%27Chaka "T'Chaka"), like his father and other Panthers
before him, concealed his country from the outside world. T'Chaka's first wife
N'Yami died while in labor with **T 'Challa**, and his second wife
[Ramonda](/wiki/Ramonda_\(comics\) "Ramonda \(comics\)") was taken prisoner by
Anton Pretorius during a visit to her homeland of [South
Africa](/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa"), so for most of his childhood
T'Challa was raised by his father alone.[38] T'Chaka was murdered by the
adventurer [Ulysses Klaw](/wiki/Klaw_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Klaw \(Marvel
Comics\)") in an attempt to seize the vibranium mound. With his people still
in danger, a young T'Challa used Klaw's sound weapon on Klaw and his men,
shattering Klaw's right hand and forcing him to flee.[39]

T'Challa was next in line to be the king of Wakanda and Black Panther, but
until he was ready to become the leader of the nation, his uncle S'yan
(T'Chaka's younger brother) successfully passed the trials to become the Black
Panther. While on his Wakandan [walkabout](/wiki/Walkabout "Walkabout") [rite
of passage](/wiki/Rite_of_passage "Rite of passage"), T'Challa met and fell in
love with apparent orphaned teen [Ororo Munroe](/wiki/Storm_\(Marvel_Comics\)
"Storm \(Marvel Comics\)"), who would grow up to become the X-Men member
Storm.[40] The two broke off their relationship due to his desire to avenge
his father's death and to become the type of man who could suitably lead
Wakanda, but they would see each other over the years when they could.

T'Challa earned the title and attributes of the Black Panther by defeating the
various champions of the Wakandan tribes. One of his first acts was to disband
and exile the Hatut Zeraze—the Wakandan [secret police](/wiki/Secret_police
"Secret police")—and its leader, his adopted brother Hunter the White
Wolf.[41] He sold off small portions of vibranium to scientific institutions
around the world, amassing a fortune which he used to arm himself with
advanced technology.[39] Later, to keep peace, he picked _dora milaje_
("adored ones") from rival tribes to serve as his personal guard and
ceremonial wives-in-training. He then studied abroad for a time before
returning to his kingship.

In his first published appearance, the now-adult T'Challa invites the American
superhero team the Fantastic Four to Wakanda, then attacks and attempts to
neutralize them individually in order to test himself to see if he is ready to
battle Klaw, who had replaced his shattered right hand with a sonic
weapon.[42][43] For their part, the Four manage to rally and stymie T'Challa
in a team counter-attack, enabling the impressed King to stand down and
explain himself to the team's satisfaction. After the ruler makes proper
amends to the Four, they befriend and help T'Challa, and he in turn aids them
against the supervillain the [Psycho-Man](/wiki/Psycho-Man "Psycho-Man").[44]
T'Challa later joins the Avengers,[45] beginning a long association with that
superhero team. He first battles the [Man-Ape](/wiki/Man-Ape "Man-Ape") while
with the group,[46] and then meets the American singer Monica Lynne,[47] with
whom he becomes romantically involved. He helps the Avengers defeat the second
[Sons of the Serpent](/wiki/Sons_of_the_Serpent "Sons of the Serpent"), and
then reveals his true identity on American television.[48] He encounters
Daredevil, and reveals to him that he had deduced Daredevil's true
identity.[49]

### Return to
Wakanda[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Return to Wakanda")]

After receiving numerous urgent official letters requesting him to return to
his increasingly troubled homeland,[50] the Panther eventually leaves his
active Avengers membership to return to a Wakanda on the brink of civil war,
bringing Lynne with him. After defeating would-be usurper Erik Killmonger and
his minions,[51] the Panther ventures to the American South to battle the Ku
Klux Klan.[52] He later gains possession of the mystical time-shifting
artifacts known as [King Solomon's Frogs](/wiki/King_Solomon%27s_Frogs "King
Solomon's Frogs").[53] These produce an alternate version of T'Challa from a
future 10 years hence, a merry, [telepathic](/wiki/Telepathy "Telepathy")
Panther with a terminal [brain aneurysm](/wiki/Cerebral_aneurysm "Cerebral
aneurysm"), whom T'Challa places in cryogenic stasis.

Later, while searching for and finding his stepmother Ramonda, the Panther
contends with South African authorities during [Apartheid](/wiki/Apartheid
"Apartheid").[54] T'Challa eventually proposes and becomes engaged to Monica
Lynne,[55] though the couple never marry.

Years later, the Panther accepts a [Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C.
"Washington, D.C.") envoy, [Everett K. Ross](/wiki/Everett_K._Ross "Everett K.
Ross"), and faces multiple threats to Wakanda's sovereignty. Ross assists him
in many of these threats. In gratitude, the Panther often risks much for Ross
in return. The first threat he and Ross encounter is "Xcon", an alliance of
rogue intelligence agents backing a coup led by the Reverend Achebe.[56]
Afterward, Killmonger resurfaces with a plot to destroy Wakanda's economy.
This forces T'Challa to [nationalize](/wiki/Nationalize "Nationalize") foreign
companies.[57] Killmonger then defeats him in ritual combat, thus inheriting
the role of Black Panther,[58] but falls into a [coma](/wiki/Coma "Coma") upon
eating the heart-shaped herb—poisonous to anyone outside the royal bloodline,
which had a hereditary immunity to its toxic effects.[59] T'Challa preserves
his rival's life rather than allowing him to die.

Later, T'Challa finds he has a brain aneurysm like his alternate future self,
and succumbs to instability and hallucinations. After his mental state almost
causes tribal warfare, the Panther hands power to his council[60] and hides in
New York City. There he mentors police officer Kasper Cole (who had adopted an
abandoned Panther costume), an experience that gives T'Challa the strength to
face his illness, reclaim his position, and return to active membership in the
Avengers, whom he helps secure special United Nations status.

### Marriage and passing the
mantle[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Marriage and passing the mantle")]

Main article: [Civil War (comics)](/wiki/Civil_War_\(comics\) "Civil War
\(comics\)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/8b/Stormbpmarriage.PNG/170px-
Stormbpmarriage.PNG)](/wiki/File:Stormbpmarriage.PNG)

[](/wiki/File:Stormbpmarriage.PNG "Enlarge")

The marriage of [Storm](/wiki/Storm_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Storm \(Marvel
Comics\)") and the Black Panther. Promotional art for _Black Panther_ #18
(Sept. 2006) by [Frank Cho](/wiki/Frank_Cho "Frank Cho").

T'Challa recounts the story of his ascension as the Black Panther in the
fourth volume of his eponymous comic book series. He defeated his uncle during
the Black Panther celebration,[61] and during his [walkabout](/wiki/Walkabout
"Walkabout") when he met and fell in love with a street urchin named Ororo in
Cairo, Egypt.[62] Unbeknownst to him the US government is planning a coup in
order to get access to the vibranium. They allow Klaw to recruit a team of
villains in order to support his totalitarian neighbor, Niganda. Klaw recruits
[Rhino](/wiki/Rhino_\(comics\) "Rhino \(comics\)"), [Black
Knight](/wiki/Black_Knight_\(comics\) "Black Knight \(comics\)"), [Batroc the
Leaper](/wiki/Batroc_the_Leaper "Batroc the Leaper"), and [Radioactive
Man](/wiki/Radioactive_Man_\(comics\) "Radioactive Man \(comics\)") to lead
the invasion. The US government then deploys an army of
[Deathloks](/wiki/Deathlok "Deathlok") to "support" T'Challa and justify an
invasion, but T'Challa kills Klaw and Storm wipes out the Deathlok army in a
hurricane.[63]

T'Challa then helps his old flame [Ororo Munroe](/wiki/Storm_\(Marvel_Comics\)
"Storm \(Marvel Comics\)") reunite with her surviving family members in Africa
and the U.S.[64] He shortly afterward proposes,[_[volume & issue
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_] and the
two are married in a large Wakandan ceremony attended by many superheroes.[65]
One of the couple's first tasks is to embark on a diplomatic tour, in which
they visit the [Inhumans](/wiki/Inhumans "Inhumans"), Doctor Doom, the
[President of the United States](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States
"President of the United States"), and [Namor](/wiki/Namor "Namor"), with only
the last one ending well.[66] After the death of [Bill
Foster](/wiki/Bill_Foster_\(comics\) "Bill Foster \(comics\)"), the Black
Panther and Storm side with Captain America's anti-registration forces.[67]
During the end battle between both sides, the Wakandan
[embassy](/wiki/Diplomatic_mission "Diplomatic mission") in
[Manhattan](/wiki/Manhattan "Manhattan") is heavily damaged, though no
Wakandans are hurt.[68] After the confrontation, the Panther and Storm briefly
fill in for vacationing Fantastic Four members [Reed](/wiki/Mister_Fantastic
"Mister Fantastic") and [Sue Richards](/wiki/Invisible_Woman "Invisible
Woman") before returning to Wakanda.[69]

Upon returning to Wakanda alone, leaving Storm in New York to aid the X-Men,
Black Panther faces Erik Killmonger, defeating him with assistance from
[Monica Rambeau](/wiki/Monica_Rambeau "Monica Rambeau") (a.k.a. Pulsar).[70]
Afterward, Wakanda fends off the alien shapeshifters the
[Skrulls](/wiki/Skrulls "Skrulls"), who had infiltrated as part of their
"[Secret Invasion](/wiki/Secret_Invasion "Secret Invasion")" plan to conquer
Earth.[71] Prince Namor attempts to recruit T'Challa for the Cabal, a secret
council of supervillains. Attacked by the forces of fellow Cabal member Doctor
Doom, T'Challa is left comatose.[72] His sister [Shuri](/wiki/Shuri_\(comics\)
"Shuri \(comics\)") is trained as the next Panther, with the mantle passing
onto her officially after T'Challa awakens from his coma and attempts to
recover from his injuries.[73]

In the aftermath, T'Challa loses all of his enhanced attributes given to him
by being the panther totem. As a result, he works with his sorcerer, Zawavari,
to accumulate a replacement.[74] He has since made a pact with another unknown
Panther deity, returning his attributes to an even higher level as well as
placing incantations on his body, making himself highly resistant to most
magic and mystic assaults. This has all been done in preparation for the
imminent battle with Doctor Doom,[75] which culminated in T'Challa rendering
all of the processed vibranium inert to give his people a chance to rebuild
without their dependence on the element.[76]

### The Man Without
Fear[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: The Man Without Fear")]

After the events of "[Shadowland](/wiki/Shadowland_\(comics\) "Shadowland
\(comics\)")", Matt Murdock (the superhero
[Daredevil](/wiki/Daredevil_\(Marvel_Comics_character\) "Daredevil \(Marvel
Comics character\)")) asks T'Challa to replace him as guardian of Hell's
Kitchen, which gives T'Challa a chance to discover himself. With the help of
[Foggy Nelson](/wiki/Foggy_Nelson "Foggy Nelson"), T'Challa assumes the
identity of **Mr. Okonkwo** , an [immigrant](/wiki/Immigrant "Immigrant") from
the [Congo](/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_Congo "Democratic Republic of Congo")
and manager of a diner called Devil's Kitchen, so that he can blend in and
learn about the denizens as an ordinary man. He gets on well with two of the
Kitchen's staff: Sofija, a migrant from [Serbia](/wiki/Serbia "Serbia") who
was formerly involved in violent [Serbian
nationalism](/wiki/Serbian_nationalism "Serbian nationalism"), and the busboy,
Brian. He also gets to know some of the neighbors from his apartment block:
Mr. Nantakarn and his son Alec, as well as Iris, a social worker assigned to
handle cases of child abuse.[77]

T'Challa finds himself up against an ambitious new crime lord, Vlad Dinu, who
styles himself "The Impaler". He also seeks an understanding with the police
through Detective Alex Kurtz. During an attempt by Vlad to terminate the
Panther, Brian from the Devil's Kitchen is seriously injured by an energy
blast from Vlad, and is reported dead. The conflict between Vlad and the
Panther becomes more personal, especially after Vlad discovers the Panther
over his wife Angela dead from a gunshot wound.[77]

T'Challa learns that Iris was the serial shooter who killed abusers of
children—Gabe was abused secretly by Angela. Brian was kidnapped by his
doctor, Dr. Holman, at the behest of Nicolae who wanted to use someone who
received a dose of Vlad's power. After being subjected to torturous
experiments, Brian lost the ability to think for himself but was rescued by
Gabe who also stole the serum produced from the experiment meant to endow the
recipient with Vlad's powers. The Panther obtains evidence of Vlad Dinu's
crimes as well as clues to Iris as the serial shooter, and turns the evidence
over to Kurtz. Vlad kills his own son Nicolae before being subdued by the
Panther. Gabe is arrested for attempting to take Iris' life. Before being
taken away, Gabe reveals to the Panther Brian's fate. Though aware of the
Panther's identity as Mr. Okonkwo, both Iris and Sofija promise to keep
silent.[77]

### Wakanda
again[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Wakanda again")]

Shortly after Daredevil returns to Hell's Kitchen, T'Challa returns to
Wakanda, serving as a second to his sister, Shuri. In preparation for an
upcoming attack on Wakanda as part of the _[Avengers vs.
X-Men](/wiki/Avengers_vs._X-Men "Avengers vs. X-Men")_ storyline, the Panther
God returns T'Challa's abilities.[78] Empowered by the Phoenix, Namor destroys
Wakanda with a massive tidal wave.[79] Returning to help, Storm is stunned
when the Panther informs her that their marriage has been annulled.[80]

###
Incursions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Incursions")]

After witnessing an alternate Earth over Wakanda being destroyed by the [Black
Swan](/wiki/Black_Swan_\(comics\) "Black Swan \(comics\)"), T'Challa reforms
the Illuminati—with Beast replacing the now-deceased Charles Xavier—to
confront the threat of the Incursions, parallel universes colliding with each
other to the destruction of both. Although able to avert one Incursion with
the Infinity Gauntlet, the subsequent destruction of the Infinity Gems forces
the group to decide to resort to more questionable measures to protect Earth
from future Incursions, wiping Captain America's mind so that he will not
remember these events, allowing them to do "what needs to be done".[81]
Although equipped with planet-destroying weapons to protect Earth, the
Illuminati mostly become disgusted with the wholesale slaughter, until Namor
breaks off from the group to form a new Cabal of villains to do what the
heroes will not. Despite Namor's Cabal achieving legitimacy as Earth's
protectors, Namor grew weary of the wholesale slaughter they carried out in
the name of preserving their universe. Although he collaborated with the
Illuminati in a plan to destroy the Cabal by trapping them on the next Earth
to be destroyed, Black Panther and Black Bolt left him behind to die with the
Cabal, disgusted at his earlier actions,[82] although Namor and the Cabal
escape to the [Ultimate universe](/wiki/Ultimate_Marvel "Ultimate Marvel")
when the other Earth has a simultaneous Incursion.[83]

### Secret
Wars[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Secret Wars")]

When the final Incursion occurs during the _[Secret
Wars](/wiki/Secret_Wars_\(2015_comic_book\) "Secret Wars \(2015 comic
book\)")_ storyline, resulting in all realities collapsing into one Earth,
Black Panther is one of the few heroes to survive the Incursion in a
specially-designed "life pod"—other survivors including [Mister
Fantastic](/wiki/Mister_Fantastic "Mister Fantastic"), [Star-Lord](/wiki/Star-
Lord "Star-Lord"), [Spider-Man](/wiki/Spider-Man "Spider-Man"), [the new
Thor](/wiki/Jane_Foster_\(comics\) "Jane Foster \(comics\)"), [Captain
Marvel](/wiki/Carol_Danvers "Carol Danvers") and a
[Phoenix](/wiki/Phoenix_Force_\(comics\) "Phoenix Force \(comics\)")-enhanced
[Cyclops](/wiki/Cyclops_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Cyclops \(Marvel
Comics\)")—although they are only released into the new world after an eight-
year stasis. Retrieved by Doctor Strange, they learn that Strange has assumed
a role of "sheriff" to Doctor Doom, who has appointed himself the god of the
new "[Battleworld](/wiki/Battleworld "Battleworld")" created from the multiple
realities.[84] Although Doom effortlessly kills Cyclops, Strange protects the
other heroes by dispersing them across Battleworld,[85] with T'Challa and
Namor eventually discovering a new version of the Infinity Gauntlet that
Strange collected, ensuring that the Gems he found would work in the location
where Doom built his main fortress.[86] Recruiting the [residents of the
deadlands](/wiki/Marvel_Zombies "Marvel Zombies") as an army, T'Challa marches
on Doom at the same time as multiple other areas rebel against him through the
encouragement of the heroes,[87] but admits when Doom confronts him that he
was only intended as a distraction while Reed targets Doom's power source. As
Reed takes Doom's power and sets out to rebuild the multiverse, T'Challa uses
the Time Gem to take himself back to Wakanda before the Incursions,
proclaiming to his people that they will lead the way to the stars and explore
new ideas.[88]

### All-New, All-Different
Marvel[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: All-New, All-Different Marvel")]

As part of the _[All-New, All-Different Marvel](/wiki/All-New,_All-
Different_Marvel "All-New, All-Different Marvel")_ , Black Panther is a member
of the [Ultimates](/wiki/Ultimates_\(2015_team\) "Ultimates \(2015
team\)").[89]

During the _[Civil War II](/wiki/Civil_War_II "Civil War II")_ storyline,
Black Panther represents Wakanda on the [Alpha Flight](/wiki/Alpha_Flight
"Alpha Flight") Space Program's [Board of Governors](/wiki/Board_of_governors
"Board of governors").[90] He sides with Captain Marvel on needing help from
an Inhuman who can predict the possible future named Ulysses Kain.[_[volume &
issue needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_]
Black Panther and Shuri take part in the fight against the Leviathon Tide.[91]

During Hydra's reign over the world led by Arnim Zola, Baron Zemo and Steve
Rogers, Panther is captured for opposing this regime, and brought into a
containing room. Once Panther and Zemo are alone, Winter Soldier rescues
Panther. Panther entrusts the unconscious Zemo to Winter Soldier, while
trailing Rogers and Zola into the secret lab. Panther finds out that Zola
infused a brainwashed Captain America with a Cosmic Cube using a stolen Stark
tech modified by Zola himself, and warns his allies to retreat from a Cosmic
Cube-powered Steve Rogers, but is too late.[92] Even though one of the heroes
knows they cannot defeat a Cosmic Cube-powered Supreme Hydra Rogers, Winter
Soldier, Captain America (Sam Wilson) and Ant-Man (Scott Lang) trick Rogers by
surrendering the last fragment of the cube to him. Winter Soldier and Ant-Man
steal the cube from Rogers before he uses its full potential, and bring back
Kobik and the real Steve Rogers.[93][94] After the defeat of Supreme Hydra
Steve Rogers, Black Panther establishes his quest to go across the universe
with his people, and found an Intergalactic Empire of Wakanda on Planet Bast,
located in the Benhazin Star System.[95]

## Powers and
abilities[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Powers and abilities")]

The title "Black Panther" is a rank of office, chieftain of the Wakandan
Panther Clan. As chieftain, the Panther is entitled to eat a special heart-
shaped herb which, in addition to his mystical, [shamanistic](/wiki/Shamanism
"Shamanism") connection with the Wakandan Panther God Bast, grants him
superhumanly acute senses, enhanced strength, speed, agility, stamina,
durability, healing, and reflexes.[96][97]

He has since lost this connection and forged a new one with another unknown
Panther deity, granting him augmented physical attributes as well as a
resistance to magic.[75] His senses are so powerful that he can pick up a
prey's scent and memorize tens of thousands of individual ones. Following his
war with Doom, T'Challa loses his enhanced abilities only to once again
establish a connection with the Panther God.[78] In addition to the resurgence
of his now superhuman abilities, he is anointed "King of the Dead", granting
him the power and knowledge of all the past Black Panthers as well as the
ability to control the [Undead](/wiki/Undead "Undead").[98] After
[Battleworld](/wiki/Secret_Wars_\(2015_comic_book\) "Secret Wars \(2015 comic
book\)") and the resurgence of the Multiverse T'challa eventually showcased
new powers in regards to his King of the Dead status, for not only could he
reanimate the dead but summon departed spirits into the physical world with
tangible form as well. Using these spiritual energies also enables him to
conjure a mythical mystical spear of glowing blue energy to his hand.[99]

T'Challa worked with his sorcerer, Zawavari, to endow T'Challa with immunity
to mystical attacks and detection in order to defeat Dr. Doom. When T'Challa's
alchemical upgrade was tested by means of Wakanda's most powerful acolytes
attacking T'Challa in unison, each mystical attack was absorbed and only
served to strengthen T'Challa. During these preparations, T'Challa invented a
potent mystical-scientific hybrid art called "shadow physics" and was able to
use it to craft shadow weapons and to track vibranium on a quantum level.[75]

As king of Wakanda, the Panther has access to a vast collection of magical
artifacts, advanced Wakandan technological and military hardware, and the
support of his nation's wide array of scientists, warriors, and mystics. The
Wakandan military has been described as one of the most powerful on Earth. His
attire is the sacred vibranium costume of the Wakandan Panther Cult.

He is a skilled hunter, tracker, strategist, politician, inventor, and
[scientist](/wiki/Scientist "Scientist"). He has a
[PhD](/wiki/Doctor_of_Philosophy "Doctor of Philosophy") in
[physics](/wiki/Physics "Physics") from [Oxford
University](/wiki/University_of_Oxford "University of Oxford"). He is
proficient in physics and advanced technology, and is also an inventor.
T'Challa has been granted the strength and knowledge of every past Black
Panther.[78]

T'Challa is rigorously trained in acrobatics and hand-to-hand combat. He is
skilled in various forms of unarmed combat, with a unique hybrid fighting
style that incorporates acrobatics and aspects of animal mimicry.[100]

The chieftain of the Wakandan Panther Clan is one of the wealthiest people in
the world, although financial estimates are difficult given Wakanda's
isolation from the world's economy and the uncertain value of Wakanda's vast
vibranium reserves and extremely advanced technologies.[101]

In _Black Panther_ volume 3, writer Christopher Priest expanded the Panther's
day-to-day arsenal to include equipment such as an "energy dagger", a
vibranium-weave suit, and a portable supercomputer, the "Kimoyo card".[102] In
_Black Panther_ volume 4, writer Reginald Hudlin introduced such specialized
equipment as "thrice-blessed armor" and "light armor" for specific tasks,[103]
and for a short while outfitted him with the [Ebony Blade](/wiki/Ebony_Blade
"Ebony Blade") of the [Black Knight](/wiki/Black_Knight_\(Dane_Whitman\)
"Black Knight \(Dane Whitman\)").[104]

## Other Black
Panthers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Other Black Panthers")]

Main article: [List of Black Panther supporting
characters](/wiki/List_of_Black_Panther_supporting_characters "List of Black
Panther supporting characters")

The mantle of the Black Panther is passed down from generation to generation
among the rulers of Wakanda[105] although it must still be deserved through a
severe selection involving the best warriors of the nation.

###
Bashenga[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Bashenga")]

Bashenga appeared for the first time in _Black Panther_ Vol. 1 #7 (January
1978) by Jack Kirby (scripts and drawings). Wise warrior at the head of the
Panther Tribe, according to legends, during the tumult where the vibranium
meteorite fell on the soil of the village, then composed of various warring
clans, he gathered all the aforementioned under his guide to defeating the
inhabitants transformed by the impact into fierce "demonic spirits", a company
which has unified the nation by founding Wakanda and becoming its first
ruler[106] and the first to obtain the title of "Black Panther" as it tells of
his "spiritual connection" with the Goddess Pantera Bast that led to the
foundation of the Cult of the Panther.[105]

###
Chanda[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Chanda")]

Chanda appeared for the first time in _Fantastic Four Unlimited_ Vol. 1 #1
(March 1993) by Roy Thomas (scripts) and Herb Trimpe (drawings). Black Panther
and ruler of Wakanda during the Second World War, Chanda is the husband of
Nanali and father of [T'Chaka](/wiki/T%27Chaka "T'Chaka") and
[S'Yan](/wiki/S%27Yan "S'Yan"); distinguished by an excessively good and
compassionate nature, he welcomed the Nazi colonel Fritz Klaue after he
crashed into his reign due to a plane crash. Over time, the two make a kind of
friendship and Klaue develops a strong obsession with the culture of Wakanda
coming to try to convince them to make their religion deist rather than
spiritist, which causes a strong friction between him and Chanda culminating
in the death of Nanali by the Nazi and in its subsequent expulsion from the
country.[107]

In several subsequent stories, T'Chaka's father (and husband of Nanali) is
called Azzuri the Wise and is presented in a completely different way from
Chanda,[108][109] leaving the doubt if it is only a sort of nickname or
another character.

###
T'Chaka[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: T'Chaka")]

Main article: [T'Chaka](/wiki/T%27Chaka "T'Chaka")

T'Chaka appeared for the first time in _Fantastic Four_ Vol. 1 #53 (August
1966) by Stan Lee (script) and Jack Kirby (art). The eldest son of King Azzuri
and Queen Nanali, T'Chaka inherits the throne and the title of the Black
Panther on his father's death by being helped in his monarch duties by his
younger brother and trusted adviser S'Yan.[110] After having married a woman
named N'Yami, believing she can not have children, she adopts a child with
her, Hunter, however, she later becomes pregnant and dies giving birth to her
first child, T'Challa; from the relationship with a woman of another tribe
T'Chaka then has a second son, Jakarra, and finally remarries with Ramonda, a
woman who grows her children as her own and from whom she has her only
daughter, Shuri,[110] but which subsequently disappears into nothingness,
leading him to believe that he has abandoned it.[38] To protect the kingdom,
T'Chaka instituted a policy of strong isolationism,[111] but in the course of
his life he often collaborated with agents of the US government.[109][112] He
is killed by Ulysses Klaw after having surprised him to illegally extract
vibranium in his kingdom.[113]

### Erik Killmonger/
N'Jadaka[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Erik Killmonger/ N'Jadaka")]

Main article: [Erik Killmonger](/wiki/Erik_Killmonger "Erik Killmonger")

In _Black Panther_ Vol. 3 #15 (February 2000), Erik Killmonger challenges and
bests T'Challa in a duel for the throne, overthrowing him as king of Wakanda
and taking on the role as the Black Panther.[114] He becomes comatose after
attempting to ingest the Heart-shaped Herb to acquire the Black Panther's
powers, as he is not of royal blood. Killmonger's time as king is short-lived
however, as he is killed by [Monica Rambeau](/wiki/Monica_Rambeau "Monica
Rambeau") during T'Challa's attack to reclaim Wakanda.[115]

###
S'Yan[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: S'Yan")]

Main article: [S'Yan](/wiki/S%27Yan "S'Yan")

S'Yan The Fast, appeared for the first time in _Black Panther_ Vol. 4 #2 (May,
2005) by Reginald Hudlin (scripts) and John Romita Jr. (drawings). The second
son of King Azzuri and Queen Nanali, S'Yan is T'Chaka's younger and trusted
advisor, after whose death, although he has no desire to reign, he agrees to
ascend the throne until his nephew became an adult.[110] Ironically, S'Yan,
who has never wanted to be king, becomes one of the most beloved monarchs in
the history of Wakanda but, nevertheless, when T'Challa returns home and
obtains the title of Black Panther, he becomes a he leaves with joy, returning
to play the role of real advisor.[110] He died during the war with Latveria to
defend Ramonda from the soldiers of Doctor Doom.

###
Shuri[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Shuri")]

Main article: [Shuri (comics)](/wiki/Shuri_\(comics\) "Shuri \(comics\)")

When T'Challa ends up in a coma because of Doctor Doom,[116] Shuri becomes his
substitute as Black Panther and queen of Wakanda which, after the rise of her
half-brother to "king of the dead", creates for the first time in history two
avatars of the Panther Goddess.

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Reception")]

Black Panther was ranked the 79th greatest comic book character by
_[Wizard](/wiki/Wizard_\(magazine\) "Wizard \(magazine\)")_ magazine.[117]
[IGN](/wiki/IGN "IGN") ranked the character the 51st greatest comic book hero,
stating that Black Panther could be considered Marvel's equivalent to
[Batman](/wiki/Batman "Batman");[118] he was also ranked tenth in their list
of "The Top 50 Avengers".[119] In 2013, [ComicsAlliance](/wiki/ComicsAlliance
"ComicsAlliance") ranked the Black Panther as #33 on their list of the "50
Sexiest Male Characters in Comics".[120]

### Volume
3[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Volume 3")]

Journalist Joe Gross praised Christopher Priest for his characterization of
the Black Panther, stating, that the writer "turned an underused icon into the
locus of a complicated high adventure by taking the Black Panther to his
logical conclusion. T'Challa (the title character) is the enigmatic ruler of a
technologically advanced, slightly xenophobic African nation, so he acts like
it". Gross applauded the title's "endless wit, sharp characterization,
narrative sophistication and explosive splash panels".[121]

Comics reviewer and journalist Mike Sangiacomo, however, criticized the
narrative structure. "Christopher Priest's fractured writing is getting on my
nerves. Like the _Spider-Man_ comics, I want to like _Black Panther_ , but
Priest's deliberately jumbled approach to writing is simply silly. I know it's
a style, but does he have to do it every issue?"[122]

Reporter Bill Radford cited similar concerns when the title had just launched.
"I appreciate the notion of seeing the Black Panther through the eyes of an
Everyman, but the Panther is almost relegated to secondary status in his own
book. And Ross' narration jumps around in time so much that I feel like his
boss, who, in trying to get Ross to tell her what has happened, complains:
'This is like watching "[Pulp Fiction](/wiki/Pulp_Fiction_\(film\) "Pulp
Fiction \(film\)")" in rewind. My head is exploding.'"[123]

### Volume
4[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Volume 4")]

_[Publishers Weekly](/wiki/Publishers_Weekly "Publishers Weekly")_ gave a
negative review to the first arc, "Who Is the Black Panther?", a modern
retelling of the character's origin, saying, "Hudlin's take is caught between
a rock and a hard place. His over-the-top narrative is not likely to appeal to
fans of the most recent version of the character, but it's too mired in
obscure Marvel continuity to attract the more general reader. The plot manages
to be convoluted without ever becoming absorbing".[124]

Journalist Shawn Jeffords, citing the lack of appearances of the title
character in the first issue, called the new series a "fairly unimpressive
launch". Jeffords also said general-audience unfamiliarity was a hindrance.
"He's never been a marquee character and to make him one will be tough".[125]

versions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=24

###
Earth-355[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=25
"Edit section: Earth-355")]

T'Challa is **Coal Tiger** , Sersi kills the Avengers and Coal Tiger is the
only survivor.[126]

### Age of
Ultron[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=26
"Edit section: Age of Ultron")]

In the _[Age of Ultron](/wiki/Age_of_Ultron "Age of Ultron")_ story, Black
Panther contacts the [Fantastic Four](/wiki/Fantastic_Four "Fantastic Four")
and informs them that [Ultron](/wiki/Ultron "Ultron") has invaded
[Earth](/wiki/Earth "Earth") with an army of Ultron Sentinels.[127] Black
Panther was later seen with [Red Hulk](/wiki/Thunderbolt_Ross "Thunderbolt
Ross") and [Taskmaster](/wiki/Taskmaster_\(comics\) "Taskmaster \(comics\)")
in Chicago spying on some Ultron Sentinels. When Taskmaster takes out a
Sentinel that was sneaking up on him, alerting the other Sentinels, Red Hulk
holds off the Sentinels while Black Panther and Taskmaster flee. During the
mayhem, Black Panther falls several stories and breaks his neck, killing him
instantly.[128]

### Amalgam
Comics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=27
"Edit section: Amalgam Comics")]

Main article: [List of Amalgam Comics
characters](/wiki/List_of_Amalgam_Comics_characters "List of Amalgam Comics
characters")

Bronze Tiger is the ruler of Wakanda and is named B'Nchalla; an amalgamation
of the [Bronze Tiger](/wiki/Bronze_Tiger "Bronze Tiger") (DC) and the Black
Panther (Marvel).

### Avengers
Forever[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=28
"Edit section: Avengers Forever")]

In _[Avengers Forever](/wiki/Avengers_Forever "Avengers Forever")_ , Captain
America and [Goliath](/wiki/Hank_Pym "Hank Pym") visit an alternate future
timeline where [Martian](/wiki/Martians_\(War_of_the_Worlds\) "Martians \(War
of the Worlds\)") invaders have ravaged the Earth. An aged Black Panther leads
this reality's version of the Avengers, who consist of
[Jocasta](/wiki/Jocasta_\(comics\) "Jocasta \(comics\)"), [Living
Lightning](/wiki/Living_Lightning "Living Lightning"),
[Killraven](/wiki/Killraven "Killraven"), [Crimson
Dynamo](/wiki/Crimson_Dynamo "Crimson Dynamo") and [Thundra](/wiki/Thundra
"Thundra").[129]

### Civil
War[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: Civil War")]

In an alternate reality where the [Civil War](/wiki/Civil_War_\(comic_book\)
"Civil War \(comic book\)") between Iron Man and Captain America never ended,
Black Panther was killed alongside [Maria Hill](/wiki/Maria_Hill "Maria Hill")
after activating [Prison 42](/wiki/Prison_42 "Prison 42")'s self-destruct
mechanism.[130] He is succeeded by his son, Azari, who takes on the Black
Panther name.[131] It is later revealed that the Black Panther who destroyed
Prison 42 was actually Queen [Veranke](/wiki/Veranke "Veranke") of the shape-
shifting alien [Skrull](/wiki/Skrull "Skrull") race, who had stolen T'Challa's
identity in order to manipulate and prolong the Civil War to suit her own
needs.[132]

###
Earth-6606[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=30
"Edit section: Earth-6606")]

T'Challa is **Chieftain Justice** , a [Captain Britain
Corps](/wiki/Captain_Britain_Corps "Captain Britain Corps") member, in
_Excalibur_ #44 (1991).[133]

### Earth
X[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=31
"Edit section: Earth X")]

In the alternate universe of _[Earth X](/wiki/Earth_X "Earth X")_ , T'Challa
has been affected by the mutative event that drives the plot. Like most of
humanity, he is mutated; in this case to become a humanoid black panther. He
is entrusted with the [Cosmic Cube](/wiki/Cosmic_Cube "Cosmic Cube") by
Captain America, who knows that T'Challa would be the only one to resist using
it and to never give it back if asked. In fact, Captain America does ask for
it back and T'Challa is forced to refuse.[134]

###
Exiles[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=32
"Edit section: Exiles")]

An alternate version of Black Panther, called simply "Panther", is drafted
onto the interdimensional superhero team the
[Exiles](/wiki/Exiles_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Exiles \(Marvel Comics\)").[135] The
Panther is the son of T'Challa and Storm and named T'Chaka, after his
grandfather. Originating from Earth-1119, he was ambushed by Klaw while
examining some ruins. Caught in Klaw's blast, the Panther was plucked out of
time and placed on the team.[135] Unlike the stoic 616-Black Panther, The
Panther is a wisecracking flirt.[135] After his assumed death on Earth-1119,
his sister took up the mantle of Black Panther.[136]

### Fox
Kids[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=33
"Edit section: Fox Kids")]

The Black Panther appears in issues #1 and #6–7 of Marvel Comics/[Fox
Kids](/wiki/Fox_Kids "Fox Kids") comic book series based on the [TV
show](/wiki/TV_show "TV show") _[The Avengers: United They
Stand](/wiki/The_Avengers:_United_They_Stand "The Avengers: United They
Stand")_.

###
Mangaverse[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=34
"Edit section: Mangaverse")]

T'Challa appears in _[Marvel Mangaverse](/wiki/Marvel_Mangaverse "Marvel
Mangaverse")_ Volume 2 as a man with a pet panther. When summoning the
spirits, T'Challa and his panther combine to become the Black Panther. He also
became The Falcon. This Black Panther was romantically attracted to
[Tigra](/wiki/Tigra "Tigra"). T'Challa's sister, T'Chana, reveals herself to
be this universe's Doctor Doom.[137]

### Marvel
2099[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=35
"Edit section: Marvel 2099")]

In the [Marvel 2099](/wiki/Marvel_2099 "Marvel 2099") continuity, a greatly
weakened Wakanda is soon to be governed by its princess, Okusana. Fearing that
she is not ready, she requests [Doom](/wiki/Doom_2099 "Doom 2099")'s help in
resurrecting **Thandaza** , her grandfather and a former Black Panther. Doom
(who claims to have agreed to the proposal out of respect for T'Challa) and
the Wakandan scientists revive Thandaza in a cyberbetic body made from
vibranium, but the plan goes awry when **Mkhalali** , the current Panther
Guard, opens fire on Thandaza, believing his resurrection to be an
abomination. The attack throws off the calibrations and leaves Thandaza in a
maddened state and constant pain, causing him to go on a bloody rampage. Doom
is ultimately forced to kill Thandaza, who thanks him for ending his
suffering.[138]

### Marvel Knights
2099[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=36
"Edit section: Marvel Knights 2099")]

Black Panther was featured in the [Marvel Knights
2099](/wiki/Marvel_2099#Marvel_Knights_2099_heroes "Marvel 2099") one shots,
which were not tied to the main 2099 continuity. A new Black Panther, **K
'Shamba**, rose to fight and thwart the mounting invasions by the successor of
Doom. While the victory over the new Doom appeared triumphant, the new
Wakandan king was ultimately revealed to be a puppet of Doom.[139]

### Marvel
Zombies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=37
"Edit section: Marvel Zombies")]

Black Panther is, for the most part, one of the few uninfected superheroes in
the alternate-universe series _[Marvel Zombies](/wiki/Marvel_Zombies "Marvel
Zombies")_ , where he is kept as a food supply for the Zombie [Giant-
Man](/wiki/Henry_Pym "Henry Pym"), who keeps the Panther imprisoned and cuts
off various limbs so that he can maintain his intelligence via a ready access
to fresh meat without infecting Panther with the zombie "virus".[140] Despite
having lost half of his right arm and his left foot, the Panther escapes—with
the severed head of zombified superheroine the
[Wasp](/wiki/Wasp_\(comics\)#Marvel_Zombies "Wasp \(comics\)") in tow[141]—and
joins forces with the mutant group the
[Acolytes](/wiki/Acolytes_\(comics\)#Marvel_Zombies "Acolytes
\(comics\)").[142] While with the Acolytes, T'Challa briefly talks with his
Earth-616 counterpart, where he expresses surprise at his marriage to Storm
but offers him all the information he can provide about the zombie
plague.[143] Decades later, T'Challa has married one of the Acolytes, Lisa
Hendricks, and they have a son, with [Forge](/wiki/Forge_\(comics\) "Forge
\(comics\)") having provided T'Challa with artificial limbs to compensate for
his injuries.[144] Facing retirement, the Panther is stabbed and critically
wounded by an agent of an Acolyte splinter group, and the Wasp— now a willing
ally after having lost her zombie hunger— zombifies the Panther in order to
grant him continued existence. With the Wasp's help, he survives to the post-
hunger stage himself and continues to lead his people, despite his
status.[145] Further internal betrayal lead the Black Panther and many of his
allies to be tossed through the dimensions.[146] He ends up involved with
another Earth that is threatened by the zombie virus. His attempts to save
this new planet fail and he is destroyed, leaving only one hand displayed as a
trophy by his enemies.[147]

###
MC2[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=38
"Edit section: MC2")]

In the [MC2](/wiki/Marvel_Comics_2 "Marvel Comics 2") universe, Black Panther
has a son named T'Chaka II, who joined the [A-Next](/wiki/A-Next "A-Next") as
the [Coal Tiger](/wiki/Coal_Tiger "Coal Tiger").[148]

### Mutant
X[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=39
"Edit section: Mutant X")]

In the _[Mutant X](/wiki/Mutant_X_\(comics\) "Mutant X \(comics\)")_ reality,
Black Panther had the appearance of a humanoid black panther. He is among the
second wave of heroes who died fighting the Beyonder.[149]

### Ultimate
Marvel[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=40
"Edit section: Ultimate Marvel")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/77/UltimateCapAmerAnl01.jpg/170px-
UltimateCapAmerAnl01.jpg)](/wiki/File:UltimateCapAmerAnl01.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:UltimateCapAmerAnl01.jpg "Enlarge")

Promotional art for _Ultimate Captain America Annual_ #1 (Dec. 2008), by
[Brandon Peterson](/wiki/Brandon_Peterson "Brandon Peterson").

In the [alternate-reality](/wiki/Parallel_universe_\(fiction\) "Parallel
universe \(fiction\)") [Ultimate Marvel](/wiki/Ultimate_Marvel "Ultimate
Marvel") [imprint](/wiki/Imprint_\(trade_name\) "Imprint \(trade name\)"), the
Black Panther is **T 'Challa Udaku**, a young man who is experimented on in
the [Weapon X](/wiki/Weapon_X "Weapon X") program before being liberated by
[Nick Fury](/wiki/Ultimate_Nick_Fury "Ultimate Nick Fury").[150]

T'Challa, the younger son of King T'Chaka of Wakanda, is severely injured
during the "Trial of the Panther" from which the protector of the nation is
selected. His older brother M'Baku finds T'Challa bloodied, mute, and near
death but derisively calls him a fool for attempting the trial. Later, M'Baku
adds that he, not T'Challa, should have taken the trial. Angry that his father
has decided to share Wakanda's technology in exchange for America's help in
saving T'Challa's life, M'Baku leaves the kingdom.

To save T'Challa, T'Chaka turns him over to the Weapon X program. Over a year
later, a healthy T'Challa, in his full Black Panther garb, has enhanced speed,
strength, night vision, and healing ability. Additionally, he can summon
short, cat-like [Adamantium](/wiki/Adamantium "Adamantium") claws from his
knuckles by balling his hands into fists. T'Chaka becomes outraged upon
learning that [S.H.I.E.L.D.](/wiki/S.H.I.E.L.D. "S.H.I.E.L.D.") (who had shut
down Weapon X and freed T'Challa) now considers his son an asset of the U.S.
and S.H.I.E.L.D. He subsequently sends M'Baku a letter, claiming that M'Baku,
not T'Challa, is the titular "favorite son", and he implores M'Baku to return.

Fury has Captain America train and mentor the Panther, who reveals his damaged
throat. Captain America, sympathizing for the Panther's plight, encourages
Fury to place the Panther in the superhero team the
[Ultimates](/wiki/Ultimates "Ultimates"). This turns out to be a ruse in which
Captain America impersonates the Panther, allowing T'Challa to escape and
return home to Wakanda.[151]

Captain America later impersonates Black Panther during an Ultimates
confrontation with the [Juggernaut](/wiki/Juggernaut_\(comics\) "Juggernaut
\(comics\)").[152]

After Ultimatum, Black Panther joins the [New Ultimates](/wiki/New_Ultimates
"New Ultimates").[153]

## In other
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=41
"Edit section: In other media")]

###
Television[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Black_Panther_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=42
"Edit section: Television")]

  * [Marvel Animation](/wiki/Marvel_Animation "Marvel Animation") and [BET](/wiki/Black_Entertainment_Television "Black Entertainment Television") began producing a primetime animated series called "[Black Panther](/wiki/Black_Panther_\(TV_series\) "Black Panther \(TV series\)")". [Djimon Hounsou](/wiki/Djimon_Hounsou "Djimon Hounsou") was cast as the voice of T'Challa / Black Panther.[154][155] The series is produced in [motion comic](/wiki/Motion_comic "Motion comic") style.[156] The world premiere of the show was in Australia, on [ABC 3](/wiki/ABC_3 "ABC 3") on January 16, 2010. The series premiered online in the US on June 23, 2010,[157] and was released on DVD in the US in January 2011.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/62/Black_Panther_Fantastic_Four_ep_20.jpg/220px-
Black_Panther_Fantastic_Four_ep_20.jpg)](/wiki/File:Black_Panther_Fantastic_Four_ep_20.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Black_Panther_Fantastic_Four_ep_20.jpg "Enlarge")

The Black Panther in the 1994 _[Fantastic
Four](/wiki/Fantastic_Four_\(1994_TV_series\) "Fantastic Four \(1994 TV
series\)")_ animated series.

  * The T'Challa version of Black Panther appeared in the "Prey of the Black Panther" episode of the 1994 _[Fantastic Four](/wiki/Fantastic_Four_\(1994_TV_series\) "Fantastic Four \(1994 TV series\)")_ animated TV series, voiced by [Keith David](/wiki/Keith_David "Keith David").[158] He enlists the Fantastic Four to help him save Wakanda from the invasion of Klaw. He makes a cameo appearance in later episode "Hopelessly Impossible".
  * The Black Panther had a non-speaking cameo in the _[X-Men](/wiki/X-Men_\(TV_series\) "X-Men \(TV series\)")_ TV series.[159]
  * In _[The Avengers: United They Stand](/wiki/The_Avengers:_United_They_Stand "The Avengers: United They Stand")_ , a portrait of the Black Panther hangs in [Avengers Mansion](/wiki/Avengers_Mansion "Avengers Mansion") in Episode 1. While the Black Panther does not appear in the animated series, he does appear in the comic book series based on the show.[160]
  * T'Challa / Black Panther appears in _[Iron Man: Armored Adventures](/wiki/Iron_Man:_Armored_Adventures "Iron Man: Armored Adventures")_ , voiced by [Jeffrey Bowyer-Chapman](/wiki/Jeffrey_Bowyer-Chapman "Jeffrey Bowyer-Chapman").[161] As seen in "Panther's Prey", he wears panther-like armor and his father was killed by [Moses Magnum](/wiki/Moses_Magnum "Moses Magnum"). He returns in the episode "Line of Fire" and the series finale "The Makluan Invasion" Parts I and II.
  * T'Challa / Black Panther appears in _[The Super Hero Squad Show](/wiki/The_Super_Hero_Squad_Show "The Super Hero Squad Show")_ , voiced by [Taye Diggs](/wiki/Taye_Diggs "Taye Diggs").[162] As seen in the episode "Tremble at the Might of MODOK", he is in a relationship with Storm.
  * The T'Challa iteration of Black Panther appears in _[The Avengers: Earth's Mightiest Heroes](/wiki/The_Avengers:_Earth%27s_Mightiest_Heroes "The Avengers: Earth's Mightiest Heroes")_, voiced by [James C. Mathis III](/wiki/James_C._Mathis_III "James C. Mathis III").[163] His origin is told in the episode "The Man in the Ant Hill" where he becomes Black Panther after Man-Ape killed T'Chaka in combat with some unseen help from Klaw. In the episode "Panther's Quest", he made himself known to the Avengers and joins them. However, in the episode "Who Do You Trust?", he leaves the team due to his uncertainty of his teammates and his need to protect Wakanda from the [Skrulls](/wiki/Skrulls "Skrulls"). He rejoins the team in the episode "Behold...The Vision!" after a battle with [Vision](/wiki/Vision_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Vision \(Marvel Comics\)"). He was thought dead in the episode "Operation Galactic Storm" when he drove a Kree ship into the sun. However, just as the ship is about to crash, Panther uses its teleporter to take him to a Kree ship on the other side of the wormhole. On the Kree ship, he steals a smaller ship, and follows the Avengers down to Hala. Panther rescued Iron Man, Vision, Hawkeye, and Thor from a monster, and helped them free the others. He then travels back to Earth with them.
  * T'Challa / Black Panther appears in episode 29 of the Japanese [anime](/wiki/Anime "Anime") series _[Marvel Disk Wars: The Avengers](/wiki/Marvel_Disk_Wars:_The_Avengers "Marvel Disk Wars: The Avengers")_ , voiced by [Mahito Ōba](/wiki/Mahito_%C5%8Cba "Mahito Ōba"). He appears in subsequent episodes as Jessica's "second hero".
  * The T'Challa iteration of Black Panther appears in the _[Avengers Assemble](/wiki/Avengers_Assemble_\(TV_series\) "Avengers Assemble \(TV series\)")_ animated series,[164] with James C. Mathis III reprising the role.[165] Introduced in the show's third season _Avengers: Ultron Revolution_ , T'Challa was first seen speaking before an assembly about Wakanda when [Crossbones](/wiki/Crossbones_\(comics\) "Crossbones \(comics\)") attacks in order to take out T'Challa. After becoming Black Panther and helping Captain America to take out Crossbones, T'Challa makes off with Captain America's shield claiming that it was stolen property. This leads [Captain America](/wiki/Captain_America "Captain America") to bring [Iron Man](/wiki/Iron_Man "Iron Man"), [Hawkeye](/wiki/Hawkeye_\(comics\) "Hawkeye \(comics\)"), and [Thor](/wiki/Thor_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Thor \(Marvel Comics\)") to [Wakanda](/wiki/Wakanda_\(comics\) "Wakanda \(comics\)") in order to reclaim it. During the confrontation, Black Panther claims that [Howard Stark](/wiki/Howard_Stark "Howard Stark") stole vibranium in order to make Captain America's shield. To make matters worse, Ulysses Klaue appears where he makes off with Captain America's shield upon using a sound attack on the group. Both sides work to find Klaue as Captain America states to Black Panther that T'Chaka gave the vibranium for Stark to make into Captain America's shield. Tracking him to a hideout in the [Himalayas](/wiki/Himalayas "Himalayas"), the Avengers and Black Panther engage Klaue in an armor made out of vibranium. With a special tactic, the Avengers and Black Panther were able to knock Klaue out of the armor as Black Panther plans to make Ulysses Klaue answer for his crimes. With Klaue's vibranium armor in Wakandan custody, Black Panther changes his opinion of the Avengers and is offered reserve membership into the group. In the show's fourth season _Avengers: Secret Wars_ , Black Panther becomes the new leader of the All-New, All-Different Avengers (consisting of himself, [Captain Marvel](/wiki/Carol_Danvers "Carol Danvers"), [Ant-Man](/wiki/Ant-Man_\(Scott_Lang\) "Ant-Man \(Scott Lang\)"), [Wasp](/wiki/Hope_Pym "Hope Pym"), [Vision](/wiki/Vision_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Vision \(Marvel Comics\)"), and [Ms. Marvel](/wiki/Kamala_Khan "Kamala Khan")) after the original team disappears. On July 22, 2017, Marvel renewed _Avengers Assemble_ for a fifth season titled _Avengers: Black Panther 's Quest_ centering around T'Challa.[166]
